sections.title: Infrared and Thermal Imaging
sections.content:
**Properties of Infrared (IR) Radiation:**
â€¢ Wavelength longer than visible light but shorter than microwaves
â€¢ All objects emit infrared radiation
â€¢ Hotter objects emit more IR radiation
â€¢ Can be felt as heat
**Thermal Imaging Applications:**
1.

 Medical diagnosis - detecting inflammation, blood flow issues
2. Building inspection - finding heat leaks, insulation problems
3. Night vision - seeing in darkness (used by military, wildlife researchers)
4. Airport screening - detecting fever during disease outbreaks (COVID-19)
5. Electrical inspection - identifying overheating components
6. Search and rescue - locating people in darkness or smoke
**How Thermal Cameras Work:**
They detect infrared radiation emitted by objects and convert it into a visible image, with different colors representing different temperatures.

sections.title: Effects of EM Radiation
sections.content:
**Beneficial Effects:**
â€¢ Radio waves - communication, broadcasting
â€¢ Microwaves - cooking, satellite communication
â€¢ Infrared - heating, thermal imaging, remote controls
â€¢ Visible light - sight, photosynthesis, lighting
â€¢ UV radiation - vitamin D production, sterilization
â€¢ X-rays - medical imaging, security scanning
â€¢ Gamma rays - cancer treatment, sterilizing medical equipment
**Harmful Effects:**
â€¢ UV radiation - skin burns, skin cancer, eye damage
â€¢ X-rays - cell damage, increased cancer risk with overexposure
â€¢ Gamma rays - severe radiation damage, mutations
**Safety Precautions:**
â€¢ Use sunscreen to protect from UV rays
â€¢ Limit X-ray exposure (only when medically necessary)
â€¢ Lead shielding for X-ray and gamma ray protection
â€¢ Follow radiation safety guidelines in hospitals

exercises.prompt: Which part of the electromagnetic spectrum has the longest wavelength?
exercises.hint: Think about the order of EM waves from low to high energy.

exercises.prompt: What is the speed of all electromagnetic waves in a vacuum?
exercises.hint: All EM waves travel at the speed of light.

exercises.prompt: How are radio waves used in astronomy?
choices: To detect radio signals from celestial objects
exercises.hint: Radio telescopes detect signals from space.

exercises.prompt: Which application uses RFID (Radio Frequency Identification) technology in Singapore?
exercises.hint: Think about contactless payment systems.

exercises.prompt: What property of infrared radiation makes it useful for thermal imaging?
choices: All objects emit infrared radiation based on their temperature
It can pass through all materials
It is visible to the human eye
exercises.hint: Hotter objects emit more IR radiation.

exercises.prompt: During COVID-19, thermal scanners at airports detected which type of EM radiation?
exercises.hint: These scanners measure body temperature.

exercises.prompt: As wavelength decreases in the EM spectrum, what happens to frequency and energy?
exercises.hint: Wavelength is inversely proportional to frequency.

exercises.prompt: Why is lead shielding used in X-ray rooms?
choices: Lead absorbs X-rays and protects people from exposure
Lead is cheaper than other materials
exercises.hint: Lead is dense and blocks radiation.

exercises.prompt: Which types of EM radiation have high energy and can be harmful to humans?
exercises.hint: High energy radiation can damage cells.

exercises.prompt: What is a beneficial use of UV radiation?
exercises.hint: UV kills bacteria and viruses.

exercises.prompt: Name the part of the EM spectrum used for cooking food quickly in microwave ovens.
exercises.hint: The answer is in the name of the oven!

exercises.prompt: What safety measure should you take to protect from excessive UV radiation from the sun?
exercises.hint: Think about what you apply to your skin.

exercises.prompt: Which EM wave is used in remote controls for TVs and air conditioners?
exercises.hint: This type of radiation can be felt as heat.

exercises.prompt: What happens to EM waves when wavelength increases?
exercises.hint: Remember: wavelength and frequency are inversely related.

exercises.prompt: Which part of the EM spectrum is used for medical imaging to see bones?
exercises.hint: This radiation can penetrate soft tissue but not bone.

chapters.title: Electromagnetism
chapters.description: Understanding magnetic fields, electromagnets and their applications in motors and generators
objectives: Describe magnetic fields around magnets and current-carrying wires
Explain how electromagnets work and factors affecting their strength
Understand the working principles of electric motors

sections.title: Magnetic Fields
sections.content:
**Magnetic Field:**
â€¢ Region where magnetic force is experienced
â€¢ Represented by magnetic field lines
â€¢ Direction: from North pole to South pole
â€¢ Stronger fields have closer field lines

**Magnetic Field Around a Bar Magnet:**
â€¢ Field lines emerge from North pole
â€¢ Field lines enter at South pole
â€¢ Field lines never cross
â€¢ Strongest at the poles

**Magnetic Field Around a Current-Carrying Wire:**
â€¢ Circular field lines around the wire
â€¢ Direction given by right-hand grip rule
â€¢ Field strength increases with current
â€¢ Field strength decreases with distance

**Magnetic Field in a Solenoid:**
â€¢ Coil of wire produces strong uniform field inside
â€¢ Field pattern similar to bar magnet
â€¢ Strength increases with:
  - More turns of wire
  - Greater current
  - Iron core inserted

sections.title: Electromagnets
sections.content:
**What is an Electromagnet?**
A coil of wire (solenoid) that becomes magnetic when current flows through it. The magnetism can be switched on and off.

**Factors Affecting Electromagnet Strength:**
1. **Number of turns** - more turns = stronger magnet
2. **Current** - larger current = stronger magnet
3. **Core material** - soft iron core makes it much stronger
4. **Core shape** - U-shaped core concentrates field

**Advantages over Permanent Magnets:**
â€¢ Can be switched on/off
â€¢ Strength can be adjusted
â€¢ Magnetic poles can be reversed
â€¢ Can be very strong

**Applications in Singapore and Worldwide:**
â€¢ MRT train door locks
â€¢ Electric bells and buzzers
â€¢ Scrapyard cranes (lifting metal)
â€¢ Circuit breakers
â€¢ Relays and switches
â€¢ Hard disk drives
â€¢ Loudspeakers
â€¢ MRI scanners in hospitals

sections.title: Electric Motors
sections.content:
**Principle:**
Electric motors convert electrical energy to kinetic energy using the motor effect (force on current-carrying wire in magnetic field).

**How a DC Motor Works:**
1. Current flows through coil in magnetic field
2. Forces act on opposite sides of coil
3. Forces cause turning effect (moment)
4. Coil rotates
5. Commutator reverses current every half turn
6. This keeps coil rotating in same direction

**Components:**
â€¢ **Coil** - carries current
â€¢ **Permanent magnets** - provide magnetic field
â€¢ **Commutator** - split ring that reverses current
â€¢ **Brushes** - maintain electrical contact

**Increasing Motor Speed:**
â€¢ Increase current
â€¢ More turns in coil
â€¢ Stronger magnets
â€¢ Better commutator design

**Applications:**
â€¢ Electric fans and air conditioners
â€¢ Electric cars and bicycles
â€¢ Washing machines and dryers
â€¢ Power tools and drills
â€¢ Computer cooling fans
â€¢ Toy cars

sections.title: Electromagnetic Induction & Generators
sections.content:
**Electromagnetic Induction:**
Voltage is induced when:
â€¢ A conductor moves through a magnetic field, OR
â€¢ The magnetic field through a conductor changes

**Faraday's Law:**
Induced voltage increases with:
â€¢ Faster movement
â€¢ Stronger magnetic field
â€¢ More turns in coil

**Lenz's Law:**
Induced current opposes the change that caused it.

**How a Generator Works:**
1. Coil rotates in magnetic field
2. Magnetic flux through coil changes
3. Voltage induced in coil
4. Current flows in external circuit
5. Slip rings maintain continuous contact

**AC Generator produces:**
â€¢ Alternating current (changes direction)
â€¢ Sinusoidal voltage output

**Applications:**
â€¢ Power stations (turbines turn generators)
â€¢ Bicycle dynamos (wheel turns generator)
â€¢ Wind turbines
â€¢ Hydroelectric dams
â€¢ Portable generators

**Energy Conversion:**
Kinetic Energy â†’ Electrical Energy

chapters.title: Inheritance & Genetics
chapters.description: Understanding DNA, genes, genetic variation and inheritance patterns
objectives: Understand the structure and function of DNA
Use genetic diagrams and Punnett squares

sections.title: DNA, Genes, and Chromosomes
sections.content:
**Genetics** is the study of how characteristics are passed from parents to offspring through genes.

**Key genetic structures:**

**1. DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)**
- **Structure**: Double helix, like a twisted ladder
- **Components**: Sugar-phosphate backbone, nitrogenous bases (A, T, G, C)
- **Base pairing**: A pairs with T, G pairs with C
- **Function**: Stores genetic information

**2. Genes**
- **Definition**: Section of DNA that codes for a specific protein
- **Function**: Determines specific characteristics (eye color, blood type, height)
- **Location**: Found on chromosomes
- **Alleles**: Different versions of the same gene (e.g., brown eye allele vs. blue eye allele)

**3. Chromosomes**
- **Structure**: Long thread of coiled DNA + proteins
- **Number in humans**: 46 chromosomes (23 pairs)
- **Types**: 22 pairs of autosomes + 1 pair of sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male)
- **Inheritance**: 23 from mother, 23 from father

**Genetic terminology:**

ğŸ”¹ **Genotype**: Genetic makeup (e.g., TT, Tt, tt)
ğŸ”¹ **Phenotype**: Physical appearance (e.g., tall or short)
ğŸ”¹ **Dominant allele**: Expressed when present (represented by capital letter, e.g., T)
ğŸ”¹ **Recessive allele**: Only expressed when paired together (lowercase letter, e.g., t)
ğŸ”¹ **Homozygous**: Two identical alleles (TT or tt)
ğŸ”¹ **Heterozygous**: Two different alleles (Tt)

**Example: Pea plant height**
- T = tall (dominant)
- t = short (recessive)

**Genotypes and phenotypes:**
- TT = tall plant (homozygous dominant)
- Tt = tall plant (heterozygous)
- tt = short plant (homozygous recessive)

**Singapore genetic diversity:**

Singapore's multicultural population shows genetic variation:
ğŸ”¹ **Eye color**: Most Asians have brown eyes (dominant allele)
ğŸ”¹ **Lactose intolerance**: Common in Asian populations (genetic variation)
ğŸ”¹ **Blood types**: A, B, AB, O distributed across ethnic groups
ğŸ”¹ **Genetic research**: Singapore Genome Project studies Asian genetic variations

sections.title: Mendelian Inheritance and Punnett Squares
sections.content:
**Gregor Mendel** (1822-1884) discovered the basic principles of inheritance through pea plant experiments.

**Mendel's Laws:**

**1. Law of Segregation**
- Each parent has two alleles for each gene
- Alleles separate during gamete (sex cell) formation
- Each gamete receives only one allele

**2. Law of Independent Assortment**
- Genes for different traits are inherited independently
- Example: Gene for height doesn't affect gene for flower color

**Punnett Square** - Tool to predict offspring genotypes

**Monohybrid cross** (one trait):

**Example: Pea plant height**
- Parents: Tt (heterozygous tall) Ã— Tt (heterozygous tall)

```
Punnett Square:
        T    t
    T  TT   Tt
    t  Tt   tt
```

**Results:**
- **Genotype ratio**: 1 TT : 2 Tt : 1 tt
- **Phenotype ratio**: 3 tall : 1 short (75% tall, 25% short)

**Types of crosses:**

**1. Homozygous dominant Ã— Homozygous recessive**
- Parents: TT Ã— tt
- Offspring: 100% Tt (all tall, heterozygous)

**2. Heterozygous Ã— Heterozygous**
- Parents: Tt Ã— Tt
- Offspring: 3 tall : 1 short

**3. Heterozygous Ã— Homozygous recessive**
- Parents: Tt Ã— tt
- Offspring: 1 Tt : 1 tt (50% tall, 50% short)

**Real-world applications:**

**Plant breeding:**
ğŸ”¹ Farmers select plants with desirable traits (high yield, disease resistance)
ğŸ”¹ Cross-pollinate to combine traits
ğŸ”¹ Singapore's urban farms use selective breeding for vegetables

**Animal breeding:**
ğŸ”¹ Breed livestock for meat quality, milk production
ğŸ”¹ Dog breeders select for specific coat colors, sizes

**Human genetics:**
ğŸ”¹ Genetic counseling predicts probability of inherited diseases
ğŸ”¹ Understanding family history of conditions (e.g., sickle cell anemia, cystic fibrosis)

**Singapore examples:**

**Blood type inheritance:**
- A and B are co-dominant, O is recessive
- Parents with type A (I^A I^O) and type B (I^B I^O) can have children with types:
  - A (I^A I^A or I^A I^O)
  - B (I^B I^B or I^B I^O)
  - AB (I^A I^B)
  - O (I^O I^O)

This is why blood donation centers (Health Sciences Authority) need diverse donors!

- ä¸åŒæ€§çŠ¶çš„åŸºå› ç‹¬ç«‹é—ä¼ 
- ä¾‹å­ï¼šé«˜åº¦åŸºå› ä¸å½±å“èŠ±è‰²åŸºå›

sections.title: Genetic Variation and Mutations
sections.content:
**Genetic variation** is the difference in DNA sequences between individuals, making each person unique (except identical twins).

**Sources of genetic variation:**

**1. Sexual reproduction**
- **Meiosis**: Process producing sex cells (gametes)
- **Random fertilization**: Any sperm can fertilize any egg
- **Crossing over**: Chromosomes exchange segments during meiosis
- **Independent assortment**: Chromosomes randomly distributed to gametes
- **Result**: Each offspring is genetically unique

**2. Mutations**
- **Definition**: Random changes in DNA sequence
- **Causes**: Radiation, chemicals, errors during DNA replication
- **Types**: Gene mutations, chromosome mutations

**Types of mutations:**

**Gene mutations** (affect single genes):

**1. Substitution** - One base replaced by another
- Example: Sickle cell disease (GAG â†’ GTG in hemoglobin gene)
- Effect: Abnormal hemoglobin protein, crescent-shaped red blood cells

**2. Insertion** - Extra base added
- Effect: Reading frame shifts, usually harmful

**3. Deletion** - Base removed
- Effect: Reading frame shifts, usually harmful

**Chromosome mutations** (affect whole chromosomes):

**1. Deletion** - Segment of chromosome lost
**2. Duplication** - Segment repeated
**3. Inversion** - Segment reversed
**4. Translocation** - Segment moved to different chromosome

**Effects of mutations:**

**Harmful mutations:**
âš ï¸ **Sickle cell disease**: Abnormal hemoglobin, painful episodes
âš ï¸ **Cystic fibrosis**: Thick mucus in lungs and digestive system
âš ï¸ **Down syndrome**: Extra chromosome 21, developmental delays

**Neutral mutations:**
ğŸ”¹ No noticeable effect on organism
ğŸ”¹ Most mutations are neutral

**Beneficial mutations:**
âœ… **Lactose tolerance**: Ability to digest milk in adulthood (evolutionary advantage)
âœ… **Antibiotic resistance in bacteria**: Allows survival (though harmful to humans!)
âœ… **Pesticide resistance in insects**: Allows survival

**Importance of genetic variation:**

âœ… **Evolution**: Raw material for natural selection
âœ… **Disease resistance**: Some individuals survive epidemics
âœ… **Adaptation**: Populations can adapt to environmental changes
âœ… **Agriculture**: Selective breeding requires genetic variation

**Genetic diseases in Singapore:**

**Thalassemia screening:**
ğŸ”¹ Common inherited blood disorder in Asian populations
ğŸ”¹ Mandatory screening for couples in Singapore
ğŸ”¹ Genetic counseling available at KKH, SGH

**Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency:**
ğŸ”¹ Common in males of Asian, African, Mediterranean descent
ğŸ”¹ Newborn screening in Singapore
ğŸ”¹ Avoid certain foods (fava beans) and medications

**Genetic testing services:**
ğŸ”¹ Available at National University Hospital
ğŸ”¹ Pre-marital screening programs
ğŸ”¹ Prenatal genetic testing (amniocentesis, chorionic villus sampling)

chapters.title: Polymers & Recycling
chapters.description: Understanding polymers, plastics and their environmental impact - NEW syllabus topic
objectives: Describe structure and properties of polymers
Describe two methods of recycling plastics
Discuss social, economic and environmental issues of recycling

sections.title: Introduction to Polymers
sections.content:
**Polymers** are large molecules made up of many small repeating units called monomers.

**Structure:**
- **Monomer**: Small molecule that joins to form polymer
- **Polymer**: Long chain of monomers linked together
- **Polymerization**: Chemical reaction joining monomers

**Types of polymers:**

**1. Natural polymers** (found in nature):
ğŸ”¹ **Proteins**: Made from amino acid monomers (silk, wool, hair)
ğŸ”¹ **Starch**: Made from glucose monomers (rice, potatoes)
ğŸ”¹ **Cellulose**: Made from glucose monomers (cotton, wood, paper)
ğŸ”¹ **DNA/RNA**: Made from nucleotide monomers
ğŸ”¹ **Natural rubber**: Made from isoprene monomers (latex from rubber trees)

**2. Synthetic polymers** (human-made):
ğŸ”¹ **Plastics**: Polyethylene (plastic bags), polypropylene (food containers)
ğŸ”¹ **Nylon**: Clothing, ropes, carpets
ğŸ”¹ **PVC (polyvinyl chloride)**: Pipes, window frames, flooring
ğŸ”¹ **Polystyrene**: Foam cups, packaging materials
ğŸ”¹ **PET (polyethylene terephthalate)**: Drink bottles, clothing fibers

**Properties of polymers:**

**Advantages:**
âœ… **Lightweight**: Easy to transport and handle
âœ… **Durable**: Resistant to corrosion, long-lasting
âœ… **Waterproof**: Don't absorb water
âœ… **Flexible or rigid**: Can be molded into different shapes
âœ… **Cheap to produce**: Lower cost than metals or glass
âœ… **Insulator**: Don't conduct electricity or heat well

**Disadvantages:**
âš ï¸ **Non-biodegradable**: Take hundreds of years to decompose
âš ï¸ **Flammable**: Burn easily, produce toxic fumes
âš ï¸ **From fossil fuels**: Made from non-renewable crude oil
âš ï¸ **Pollution**: Accumulate in environment, harm wildlife

**Common plastic codes in Singapore:**

**1. PET (1)** - Water bottles, soft drink bottles
**2. HDPE (2)** - Milk jugs, shampoo bottles
**3. PVC (3)** - Pipes, window frames
**4. LDPE (4)** - Plastic bags, squeeze bottles
**5. PP (5)** - Food containers, bottle caps
**6. PS (6)** - Foam cups, food trays
**7. Others** - Mixed plastics, CDs

**Singapore examples:**

ğŸ”¹ **HDB buildings**: PVC pipes for plumbing
ğŸ”¹ **Food packaging**: Polypropylene containers at hawker centers
ğŸ”¹ **Drink bottles**: PET bottles at supermarkets (FairPrice, Giant, Sheng Siong)
ğŸ”¹ **MRT seats**: Synthetic polymer fabrics for durability

sections.title: Plastic Pollution and Environmental Impact
sections.content:
**Plastic pollution** is one of the most serious environmental problems facing the world today.

**The problem:**

**Global plastic production:**
- 400+ million tonnes produced annually worldwide
- Only 9% is recycled
- 12% is incinerated
- 79% ends up in landfills or environment

**Why is plastic pollution harmful?**

**1. Non-biodegradable**
- Takes 450+ years to decompose
- Breaks into microplastics (< 5mm), never fully disappears
- Accumulates in environment over time

**2. Marine pollution**
- 8 million tonnes enter oceans annually
- Forms "garbage patches" (Great Pacific Garbage Patch = 1.6 million kmÂ²)
- Fish, turtles, seabirds mistake plastic for food
- Entanglement in plastic debris (fishing nets, six-pack rings)

**3. Microplastics**
- Found in food chain (fish, salt, drinking water)
- Present in human blood and organs
- Health effects still being studied
- Cannot be filtered out easily

**4. Toxic chemicals**
- Plastics contain additives (phthalates, BPA)
- Leach into food, water, soil
- Disrupt hormones, affect reproduction

**5. Greenhouse gas emissions**
- Production from fossil fuels releases COâ‚‚
- Incineration releases COâ‚‚ and toxic fumes
- Decomposition releases methane

**Singapore's plastic problem:**

**Waste statistics:**
ğŸ”¹ **1.76 million tonnes plastic waste** generated in 2022
ğŸ”¹ **Only 6% recycled** (very low!)
ğŸ”¹ **Rest incinerated** at waste-to-energy plants
ğŸ”¹ **Ash sent to Pulau Semakau** offshore landfill (limited capacity)

**Sources of plastic waste:**
- Packaging (food delivery, online shopping)
- Single-use plastics (bags, straws, utensils)
- Beverage bottles and cans
- Styrofoam food containers

**Marine pollution around Singapore:**
- Plastic debris washes up on beaches (East Coast Park, Sentosa)
- Harms marine life in Johor Straits
- Microplastics found in fish sold at wet markets

**Common single-use plastics in Singapore:**

âš ï¸ **Plastic bags**: Supermarkets, shops (FairPrice, NTUC)
âš ï¸ **Straws and cutlery**: Hawker centers, food courts
âš ï¸ **Food containers**: Takeaway packaging, bubble tea cups
âš ï¸ **Bubble wrap**: Online shopping deliveries (Lazada, Shopee)
âš ï¸ **Styrofoam boxes**: Wet market meat, fish packaging

**Impact on wildlife:**

ğŸ”¹ **Sea turtles**: Mistake plastic bags for jellyfish, choke
ğŸ”¹ **Seabirds**: Fill stomachs with plastic, starve
ğŸ”¹ **Fish**: Ingest microplastics, bioaccumulation in food chain
ğŸ”¹ **Coral reefs**: Plastic debris smothers coral (Sisters' Islands Marine Park)

**Solutions discussed:**

âœ… Reduce single-use plastics
âœ… Reusable bags, bottles, containers
âœ… Proper recycling in blue bins
âœ… Support plastic-free initiatives
âœ… Choose products with less packaging

(Detailed solutions in next section: Recycling & Sustainability)

sections.title: Recycling and Sustainable Solutions
sections.content:
**Recycling** is the process of collecting and processing materials to make new products, reducing waste and conserving resources.

**Why recycle plastics?**

âœ… **Conserves resources**: Saves crude oil (raw material for plastics)
âœ… **Saves energy**: Recycling uses less energy than making new plastic
âœ… **Reduces waste**: Less plastic in landfills and incinerators
âœ… **Protects environment**: Less pollution, less harm to wildlife
âœ… **Economic benefits**: Creates jobs, saves money on raw materials

**Plastic recycling process:**

**Step 1: Collection**
- Separate plastics into blue recycling bins
- Check plastic code (1-7) on bottom of container
- Remove food residue, rinse clean

**Step 2: Sorting**
- Plastics sorted by type (PET, HDPE, PP, etc.)
- Manual and automated sorting at recycling facilities
- Contaminated plastics removed

**Step 3: Shredding**
- Plastics shredded into small flakes
- Easier to process and melt

**Step 4: Washing**
- Remove labels, adhesives, dirt
- Clean plastic flakes ready for processing

**Step 5: Melting and pelletizing**
- Plastic flakes melted and formed into pellets
- Pellets used as raw material for new products

**Step 6: Manufacturing**
- Pellets made into new products:
  - Clothing (fleece jackets from PET bottles)
  - Furniture (park benches from recycled plastic)
  - Containers (new bottles, food containers)
  - Building materials (plastic lumber, tiles)

**Singapore's recycling initiatives:**

**National Recycling Programme:**
ğŸ”¹ **Blue recycling bins**: In HDB estates, condominiums, landed properties
ğŸ”¹ **Collection schedule**: Weekly or fortnightly pickup
ğŸ”¹ **Accepted items**: Paper, plastic, metal, glass

**What can be recycled:**
âœ… Plastic bottles (PET #1)
âœ… Detergent bottles (HDPE #2)
âœ… Food containers (PP #5)
âœ… Milk jugs, shampoo bottles
âœ… Plastic bags (clean and dry)

**What CANNOT be recycled:**
âŒ Styrofoam (polystyrene foam)
âŒ Food-contaminated plastic
âŒ Plastic straws, cutlery (too small)
âŒ Disposable diapers
âŒ Crisp packets, candy wrappers

**Sustainable alternatives to single-use plastics:**

**At hawker centers and food courts:**
ğŸ”¹ **Bring own containers**: For takeaway food (some hawkers give discounts!)
ğŸ”¹ **Refuse plastic bags**: Dine in or bring reusable bags
ğŸ”¹ **Use metal straws**: Or skip straws entirely

**At supermarkets:**
ğŸ”¹ **Reusable shopping bags**: Bring own bags (FairPrice, Giant, Cold Storage)
ğŸ”¹ **Buy loose produce**: Avoid pre-packaged fruits/vegetables
ğŸ”¹ **Choose products with less packaging**: Bulk buying reduces waste

**For drinks:**
ğŸ”¹ **Reusable water bottles**: Refill at water fountains (MRT stations, malls)
ğŸ”¹ **Bring own cup**: For coffee/tea (some cafes give discounts)
ğŸ”¹ **Glass bottles**: Choose glass over plastic when possible

**Government initiatives:**

**Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) for e-waste:**
- Manufacturers responsible for collecting and recycling products
- Coming soon for packaging waste

**Disposable carrier bag charge:**
- Supermarkets charge for plastic bags (encourage reusable bags)

**Zero Waste Masterplan:**
- Goal: 70% recycling rate by 2030
- Reduce waste sent to Pulau Semakau landfill
- Extend landfill lifespan beyond 2035

**What YOU can do:**

**Reduce:**
ğŸ”¹ Say no to single-use plastics
ğŸ”¹ Choose products with minimal packaging
ğŸ”¹ Buy only what you need

**Reuse:**
ğŸ”¹ Use reusable bags, bottles, containers
ğŸ”¹ Repair broken items instead of replacing
ğŸ”¹ Donate or sell unwanted items

**Recycle:**
ğŸ”¹ Clean and sort recyclables properly
ğŸ”¹ Check plastic codes before recycling
ğŸ”¹ Participate in recycling programs

**Singapore success stories:**

ğŸ”¹ **Bring Your Own (BYO) movement**: Many cafes encourage reusable cups
ğŸ”¹ **Plastic-free initiatives**: Some supermarkets offer paper bags
ğŸ”¹ **Recycling bins at MRT stations**: Easy access to recycling
ğŸ”¹ **Second-hand markets**: Carousell, flea markets reduce waste

Every Singaporean's small actions add up to big environmental impact!

chapters.title: Pressure in Fluids
chapters.description: Understanding pressure in liquids and gases, atmospheric pressure and applications
objectives: Calculate pressure in liquids and gases
Explain atmospheric pressure and its effects

sections.title: Pressure in Liquids
sections.content:
**Pressure** is the force acting per unit area.

**Formula:** Pressure = Force / Area
**Units:** Pascal (Pa) or N/mÂ²

**Pressure in liquids:**

Liquids exert pressure in all directions because:
ğŸ”¹ Liquid particles are free to move
ğŸ”¹ Weight of liquid above creates pressure
ğŸ”¹ Pressure acts perpendicular to surfaces

**Key principles:**

**1. Pressure increases with depth**
- Deeper you go, more liquid above you
- Formula: P = Ïgh
  - P = pressure (Pa)
  - Ï (rho) = density of liquid (kg/mÂ³)
  - g = gravitational field strength (10 N/kg)
  - h = depth below surface (m)

**2. Pressure is the same at the same depth**
- All points at same depth have equal pressure
- Doesn't matter the shape of container

**3. Pressure acts in all directions**
- Liquid pressure pushes on all sides equally

**Calculating liquid pressure:**

**Example: Swimming pool**
- Depth: 2 m
- Density of water: 1000 kg/mÂ³
- g = 10 N/kg

P = Ïgh = 1000 Ã— 10 Ã— 2 = 20,000 Pa = 20 kPa

**Singapore examples:**

**Reservoirs:**
ğŸ”¹ **Marina Barrage**: Water pressure at dam base is high due to depth
ğŸ”¹ **Swimming pools**: Deeper end has higher water pressure
ğŸ”¹ **HDB water tanks**: Placed on rooftop to create pressure for taps below

**Diving:**
ğŸ”¹ **Sentosa Underwater World**: Divers feel pressure increase with depth
ğŸ”¹ **Scuba diving**: Every 10 m depth adds ~100 kPa pressure
ğŸ”¹ **Submarines**: Built strong to withstand deep ocean pressure

**Water supply:**
ğŸ”¹ **PUB water towers**: Height creates pressure for water distribution
ğŸ”¹ **Gravity-fed system**: Water flows from reservoirs to homes
ğŸ”¹ **HDB flats**: Lower floors have higher water pressure than top floors

sections.title: Atmospheric Pressure
sections.content:
**Atmospheric pressure** is the pressure exerted by the weight of air in the atmosphere.

**What causes atmospheric pressure?**

ğŸ”¹ Air has mass (mixture of gases)
ğŸ”¹ Gravity pulls air molecules down
ğŸ”¹ Weight of air above creates pressure
ğŸ”¹ Air extends ~100 km above Earth's surface

**Atmospheric pressure at sea level:**
- **1 atmosphere (atm)** = 101,325 Pa = 101.3 kPa
- Equivalent to weight of 10 m column of water
- Or 760 mm column of mercury

**Factors affecting atmospheric pressure:**

**1. Altitude (height above sea level)**
- Higher altitude â†’ less air above â†’ lower pressure
- Pressure decreases by ~12 Pa per meter climb

**2. Weather conditions**
- High pressure: Clear, sunny weather
- Low pressure: Cloudy, rainy weather

**Measuring atmospheric pressure:**

**Barometer** - Instrument to measure air pressure

**Mercury barometer:**
- Glass tube filled with mercury, inverted in dish
- Atmospheric pressure pushes mercury up tube
- Height of mercury column = atmospheric pressure
- Standard: 760 mm Hg at sea level

**Aneroid barometer:**
- Metal box with partial vacuum inside
- Atmospheric pressure compresses/expands box
- Dial shows pressure reading
- Used in weather stations, altimeters

**Effects of atmospheric pressure:**

**Drinking through a straw:**
1. Suck air out of straw
2. Pressure inside straw decreases
3. Atmospheric pressure on drink surface pushes liquid up straw

**Suction cups:**
1. Press cup on smooth surface
2. Air pushed out from under cup
3. Atmospheric pressure on outside holds cup in place

**Vacuum packaging:**
1. Remove air from bag
2. Atmospheric pressure compresses bag tightly around food
3. Prevents spoilage, extends shelf life

**Singapore applications:**

**Weather forecasting:**
ğŸ”¹ **Meteorological Service Singapore**: Monitors atmospheric pressure
ğŸ”¹ **High pressure**: Expect sunny weather (typical in Singapore)
ğŸ”¹ **Low pressure**: Expect rain or thunderstorms

**Aviation:**
ğŸ”¹ **Changi Airport**: Aircraft altimeters use pressure to determine altitude
ğŸ”¹ **Cabin pressure**: Planes pressurized to ~0.8 atm for passenger comfort

**Vacuum-sealed products:**
ğŸ”¹ **Coffee**: Vacuum-packed to preserve freshness (supermarkets)
ğŸ”¹ **Electronics**: Moisture-sensitive components stored in vacuum bags

**Building design:**
ğŸ”¹ **Wind pressure**: Atmospheric pressure differences create wind forces on tall buildings (Marina Bay Sands)
ğŸ”¹ **Ventilation**: Pressure differences drive air circulation in HDB flats

sections.title: Applications of Pressure in Fluids
sections.content:
**Hydraulic systems** use liquid pressure to transmit force and do work.

**Pascal's Principle:**
- Pressure applied to enclosed fluid is transmitted equally in all directions
- Used in hydraulic systems to multiply force

**Hydraulic jack/lift:**

**How it works:**
1. **Small piston** (area Aâ‚) pushed with small force Fâ‚
2. **Pressure created**: P = Fâ‚/Aâ‚
3. **Same pressure** transmitted to large piston (area Aâ‚‚)
4. **Large force produced**: Fâ‚‚ = P Ã— Aâ‚‚

**Force multiplication:**
- If Aâ‚‚ = 10 Ã— Aâ‚, then Fâ‚‚ = 10 Ã— Fâ‚
- Small effort force lifts heavy load

**Applications:**

**Car brake system:**
1. Driver pushes brake pedal (small force)
2. Pressure transmitted through brake fluid
3. Brake pads pressed against wheels (large force)
4. Car slows down

**Hydraulic car lift** (workshop):
- Mechanic applies small force on pump
- Lifts entire car for repairs

**Hydraulic excavator:**
- Controls arm movements
- Digs with great force

**Pneumatic systems** use compressed air instead of liquid:

**Pneumatic drill:**
- Compressed air drives piston rapidly
- Used for breaking concrete, road repairs

**Automatic doors:**
- Compressed air opens/closes doors
- Used in MRT stations, shopping malls

**Singapore applications:**

**MRT system:**
ğŸ”¹ **Hydraulic doors**: Train doors use hydraulic/pneumatic systems
ğŸ”¹ **Brake systems**: Hydraulic brakes stop trains safely
ğŸ”¹ **Platform screen doors**: Pneumatic systems open/close automatically

**Construction:**
ğŸ”¹ **Pile drivers**: Hydraulic systems drive foundation piles for HDB buildings
ğŸ”¹ **Cranes**: Hydraulic lifts for construction at building sites
ğŸ”¹ **Concrete pumps**: Hydraulic pressure pumps concrete to high floors

**Automotive:**
ğŸ”¹ **Car workshops**: Hydraulic lifts at Ubi, Sin Ming car repair shops
ğŸ”¹ **Brake systems**: All vehicles in Singapore use hydraulic brakes
ğŸ”¹ **Power steering**: Hydraulic assistance for easier steering

**Advantages of hydraulic systems:**
âœ… Multiply force easily
âœ… Smooth, precise control
âœ… Can transmit force over distance (through pipes)
âœ… Reliable and durable

**Disadvantages:**
âš ï¸ Leaks can reduce pressure
âš ï¸ Fluid needs replacement/maintenance
âš ï¸ Heavy and expensive
âš ï¸ Fire risk if hydraulic fluid is flammable

**Buoyancy and floating:**

**Archimedes' Principle:**
- Object in fluid experiences upward force (buoyant force)
- Buoyant force = weight of fluid displaced

**Floating:**
- If buoyant force â‰¥ weight of object, it floats
- Ships float because they displace large volume of water

**Singapore maritime:**
ğŸ”¹ **Port of Singapore**: Container ships float despite heavy cargo
ğŸ”¹ **Ferries**: Sentosa ferry, Pulau Ubin bumboat use buoyancy
ğŸ”¹ **Navy ships**: RSS ships at Changi Naval Base designed to float efficiently

chapters.title: Quantitative Chemistry
chapters.description: Understanding the mole concept, chemical calculations and stoichiometry
objectives: Understand the mole concept and Avogadro's constant
Calculate relative molecular mass and molar mass
Calculate percentage composition and empirical formula

sections.title: Relative Atomic Mass and Mole Concept
sections.content:
**Quantitative chemistry** deals with calculating amounts of substances in chemical reactions.

**Relative Atomic Mass (Ar):**

- **Definition**: Mass of one atom compared to 1/12 the mass of one carbon-12 atom
- **No units** (it's a ratio)
- Found on Periodic Table

**Examples:**
- Hydrogen (H): Ar = 1
- Carbon (C): Ar = 12
- Oxygen (O): Ar = 16
- Sodium (Na): Ar = 23
- Chlorine (Cl): Ar = 35.5

**Relative Molecular Mass (Mr) / Relative Formula Mass:**

- **Definition**: Sum of relative atomic masses of all atoms in a molecule
- **No units**

**Calculating Mr:**

**Example 1: Water (Hâ‚‚O)**
- Mr = (2 Ã— 1) + (1 Ã— 16) = 2 + 16 = 18

**Example 2: Carbon dioxide (COâ‚‚)**
- Mr = (1 Ã— 12) + (2 Ã— 16) = 12 + 32 = 44

**Example 3: Sodium chloride (NaCl)**
- Formula mass = (1 Ã— 23) + (1 Ã— 35.5) = 58.5

**The Mole (mol):**

- **Definition**: Amount of substance containing 6.02 Ã— 10Â²Â³ particles (Avogadro's number)
- **1 mole** of any substance contains **6.02 Ã— 10Â²Â³** atoms, molecules, or ions

**Why use moles?**
ğŸ”¹ Atoms are too small and numerous to count individually
ğŸ”¹ Mole allows us to count particles by weighing
ğŸ”¹ Links mass to number of particles

**Molar mass:**
- **Definition**: Mass of one mole of a substance
- **Units**: g/mol
- **Numerically equal to Ar or Mr**

**Examples:**
- 1 mole of carbon (C) = 12 g
- 1 mole of water (Hâ‚‚O) = 18 g
- 1 mole of sodium chloride (NaCl) = 58.5 g

**Formula:**

**Number of moles = Mass (g) / Molar mass (g/mol)**

**Example calculations:**

**Q: How many moles in 36 g of water (Hâ‚‚O)?**

1. Find molar mass of Hâ‚‚O: Mr = 18 g/mol
2. Apply formula: moles = 36 / 18 = 2 mol

**Q: What is the mass of 0.5 mol of sodium chloride (NaCl)?**

1. Molar mass of NaCl = 58.5 g/mol
2. Rearrange formula: mass = moles Ã— molar mass
3. mass = 0.5 Ã— 58.5 = 29.25 g

**Singapore context:**

**Chemistry practical:**
ğŸ”¹ Sec 3 students weigh chemicals in moles for experiments
ğŸ”¹ Calculate amounts needed for reactions
ğŸ”¹ Used in titration experiments at school labs

**Industrial applications:**
ğŸ”¹ **Chemical plants** (Jurong Island): Calculate reactant amounts in tonnes
ğŸ”¹ **Pharmaceutical companies**: Precise mole calculations for medicine production
ğŸ”¹ **Water treatment** (PUB): Calculate chemical dosages for purification

sections.title: Chemical Equations and Stoichiometry
sections.content:
**Stoichiometry** is the study of quantitative relationships in chemical reactions.

**Balanced chemical equations** show:
1. **Reactants** â†’ **Products**
2. **Ratio of moles** of substances involved
3. **Law of conservation of mass**: Atoms are not created or destroyed

**Example: Formation of water**

2Hâ‚‚ + Oâ‚‚ â†’ 2Hâ‚‚O

**Interpretation:**
- **Molecules**: 2 molecules Hâ‚‚ + 1 molecule Oâ‚‚ â†’ 2 molecules Hâ‚‚O
- **Moles**: 2 mol Hâ‚‚ + 1 mol Oâ‚‚ â†’ 2 mol Hâ‚‚O
- **Mole ratio**: Hâ‚‚ : Oâ‚‚ : Hâ‚‚O = 2 : 1 : 2

**Steps for stoichiometry calculations:**

**Step 1**: Write balanced equation
**Step 2**: Find mole ratio from equation
**Step 3**: Calculate moles of known substance
**Step 4**: Use mole ratio to find moles of unknown substance
**Step 5**: Convert moles to mass (if needed)

**Example calculation:**

**Q: What mass of oxygen is needed to react completely with 4 g of hydrogen to form water?**

**Step 1**: Balanced equation: 2Hâ‚‚ + Oâ‚‚ â†’ 2Hâ‚‚O

**Step 2**: Mole ratio: Hâ‚‚ : Oâ‚‚ = 2 : 1

**Step 3**: Moles of Hâ‚‚ = mass / molar mass = 4 / 2 = 2 mol

**Step 4**: Moles of Oâ‚‚ = 2 mol Hâ‚‚ Ã— (1 mol Oâ‚‚ / 2 mol Hâ‚‚) = 1 mol

**Step 5**: Mass of Oâ‚‚ = moles Ã— molar mass = 1 Ã— 32 = 32 g

**Answer**: 32 g of oxygen needed

**Limiting reactant:**

- **Definition**: Reactant that is completely used up first
- Determines maximum amount of product formed
- Other reactants are in excess

**Example:**

**Q: 6 g of hydrogen reacts with 32 g of oxygen. Which is the limiting reactant? What mass of water is formed?**

**Equation**: 2Hâ‚‚ + Oâ‚‚ â†’ 2Hâ‚‚O

**Moles of Hâ‚‚**: 6 / 2 = 3 mol
**Moles of Oâ‚‚**: 32 / 32 = 1 mol

**From equation**: 2 mol Hâ‚‚ needs 1 mol Oâ‚‚
**For 3 mol Hâ‚‚**: needs 1.5 mol Oâ‚‚

**We only have 1 mol Oâ‚‚**, so **Oâ‚‚ is the limiting reactant**

**Maximum Hâ‚‚O formed**: 1 mol Oâ‚‚ produces 2 mol Hâ‚‚O
**Mass of Hâ‚‚O**: 2 Ã— 18 = 36 g

**Percentage yield:**

**Theoretical yield**: Maximum amount of product calculated from equation
**Actual yield**: Amount of product actually obtained in experiment

**Formula:**

**% yield = (Actual yield / Theoretical yield) Ã— 100%**

**Why is actual yield < theoretical yield?**
âš ï¸ Incomplete reactions
âš ï¸ Side reactions producing unwanted products
âš ï¸ Loss of product during transfer/purification
âš ï¸ Impure reactants

**Singapore applications:**

**Industrial chemistry (Jurong Island):**
ğŸ”¹ **Fertilizer production**: Calculate reactant amounts for ammonia synthesis
ğŸ”¹ **Petrochemicals**: Optimize yields to maximize profit
ğŸ”¹ **Cost efficiency**: Minimize waste, reduce reactant costs

**Environmental:**
ğŸ”¹ **NEWater production**: Calculate chemical dosages for water treatment
ğŸ”¹ **Pollution control**: Calculate amounts of neutralizing agents for waste treatment

**Medicine:**
ğŸ”¹ **Drug synthesis**: Precise stoichiometry ensures correct drug composition
ğŸ”¹ **Quality control**: Calculate expected vs. actual yields

sections.title: Concentration and Solution Calculations
sections.content:
**Concentration** measures the amount of solute dissolved in a solution.

**Types of concentration:**

**1. Mass concentration (g/dmÂ³)**
- **Definition**: Mass of solute per unit volume of solution
- **Units**: g/dmÂ³ or g/L
- **Formula**: Concentration = Mass of solute (g) / Volume of solution (dmÂ³)

**Example:**
- 20 g of salt dissolved in 2 dmÂ³ of water
- Concentration = 20 / 2 = 10 g/dmÂ³

**2. Molar concentration / Molarity (mol/dmÂ³ or M)**
- **Definition**: Number of moles of solute per unit volume of solution
- **Units**: mol/dmÂ³ or M (molar)
- **Formula**: Concentration = Moles of solute / Volume of solution (dmÂ³)

**Example:**
- 0.5 mol of sodium chloride in 2 dmÂ³ of solution
- Concentration = 0.5 / 2 = 0.25 mol/dmÂ³ or 0.25 M

**Key conversions:**
- 1 dmÂ³ = 1 L = 1000 cmÂ³ = 1000 mL
- To convert cmÂ³ to dmÂ³: divide by 1000

**Calculation triangle for solutions:**

```
        Mass (g)
       /        \
      /          \
Moles (mol)  â†â†’  Concentration (mol/dmÂ³) Ã— Volume (dmÂ³)
```

**Formula:**

**Moles = Concentration (mol/dmÂ³) Ã— Volume (dmÂ³)**
**Mass = Moles Ã— Molar mass**
**Concentration = Moles / Volume**

**Example problems:**

**Q1: What is the concentration of a solution containing 0.2 mol of NaCl in 500 cmÂ³?**

**Step 1**: Convert volume to dmÂ³: 500 cmÂ³ = 500/1000 = 0.5 dmÂ³
**Step 2**: Calculate concentration: C = moles / volume = 0.2 / 0.5 = 0.4 mol/dmÂ³

**Answer**: 0.4 mol/dmÂ³

**Q2: How many moles of HCl are in 250 cmÂ³ of 2 mol/dmÂ³ HCl?**

**Step 1**: Convert volume: 250 cmÂ³ = 0.25 dmÂ³
**Step 2**: Calculate moles: moles = C Ã— V = 2 Ã— 0.25 = 0.5 mol

**Answer**: 0.5 mol

**Q3: What mass of copper sulfate (CuSOâ‚„) is needed to make 500 cmÂ³ of 0.1 mol/dmÂ³ solution?**

**Step 1**: Find molar mass of CuSOâ‚„: Mr = 64 + 32 + (4Ã—16) = 160 g/mol
**Step 2**: Convert volume: 500 cmÂ³ = 0.5 dmÂ³
**Step 3**: Calculate moles: moles = C Ã— V = 0.1 Ã— 0.5 = 0.05 mol
**Step 4**: Calculate mass: mass = moles Ã— molar mass = 0.05 Ã— 160 = 8 g

**Answer**: 8 g

**Dilution:**

- **Definition**: Adding solvent (usually water) to decrease concentration
- **Key principle**: Moles of solute remain constant

**Formula:**

**Câ‚Vâ‚ = Câ‚‚Vâ‚‚**

where:
- Câ‚ = initial concentration
- Vâ‚ = initial volume
- Câ‚‚ = final concentration
- Vâ‚‚ = final volume

**Example:**

**Q: 100 cmÂ³ of 2 mol/dmÂ³ NaOH is diluted to 500 cmÂ³. What is the new concentration?**

Câ‚Vâ‚ = Câ‚‚Vâ‚‚
(2)(100) = (Câ‚‚)(500)
Câ‚‚ = 200 / 500 = 0.4 mol/dmÂ³

**Answer**: 0.4 mol/dmÂ³

**Singapore applications:**

**Chemistry practicals:**
ğŸ”¹ **Titration experiments**: Prepare standard solutions of acids/bases
ğŸ”¹ **Concentration calculations**: Determine unknown concentrations
ğŸ”¹ **Dilution**: Make working solutions from stock solutions

**Industry:**
ğŸ”¹ **Water treatment (PUB)**: Calculate chlorine concentration in tap water
ğŸ”¹ **Food industry**: Concentration of preservatives, flavorings
ğŸ”¹ **Pharmaceutical**: Precise drug concentrations in medicines

**Daily life:**
ğŸ”¹ **Cleaning products**: Dilute concentrated bleach for home use
ğŸ”¹ **Drinks**: Concentrated juice diluted with water (Ribena, Yakult)
ğŸ”¹ **Pool maintenance**: Chlorine concentration in swimming pools

chapters.title: Static Electricity
chapters.description: Understanding electric charge, electrostatic forces and applications
objectives: Explain how objects become charged by friction
Describe the forces between charged objects
Explain electrostatic phenomena in everyday life
Understand applications and hazards of static electricity

sections.title: Electric Charge
sections.content:
**Types of Charge:**
â€¢ Positive charge (+)
â€¢ Negative charge (-)
â€¢ Neutral (equal positive and negative)

**Properties:**
â€¢ Like charges repel
â€¢ Unlike charges attract
â€¢ Charge is conserved (cannot be created or destroyed)
â€¢ Charge can be transferred

**Charging by Friction:**
When two materials are rubbed together:
â€¢ Electrons transfer from one material to the other
â€¢ Material losing electrons becomes positive
â€¢ Material gaining electrons becomes negative

**Examples:**
â€¢ Rubbing balloon on hair - balloon becomes negative
â€¢ Rubbing plastic rod with cloth - rod becomes negative
â€¢ Combing hair - comb becomes charged

subjects.title: AI Playground
subjects.description: Explore AI through hands-on activities with text, images, music, video, and code

subjects.title: Computing
subjects.description: Learn computational thinking, programming, and digital systems

chapters.title: Digital Devices & Systems
chapters.description: Computer hardware, input/output devices, and how computers work
objectives: Recognize different types of computing devices

sections.title: Main Computer Components
sections.content:
**CPU** (Central Processing Unit) is the brain - processes instructions. **RAM** (Random Access Memory) is temporary storage - holds data while computer is on.

Storage (Hard Drive/**SSD**) is permanent storage - saves files.

Motherboard connects all components. 

**Example:**

 Singapore student doing homework - **CPU **processes calculations, **RAM **holds open documents, storage saves completed work.

sections.title: Input & Output Devices
sections.content:
Input devices send data **TO **computer: Keyboard (text), Mouse (pointing), Microphone (sound), Camera (images/video), Scanner (documents).

Output devices receive data **FROM **computer: Monitor (display), Printer (paper), Speakers (sound), Headphones (audio).

Some devices are both: Touchscreen (input touch, output display), **VR **headset.

Singapore schools use interactive whiteboards - both input and output.

sections.title: How Computers Process Data
sections.content:
Input-Process-Output cycle:
1.

Input: User enters data (keyboard/mouse)
2.

Process: **CPU **executes instructions using **RAM
**3.

Output: Results displayed or saved. 

**Example:**

 Singapore student searches online - Input: Type 'Singapore history', Process: Computer sends request to Google servers, retrieves results, Output: Display search results on screen.

Everything happens in milliseconds!

sections.title: Types of Computing Devices
sections.content:
Desktop computers: Powerful, stationary, used at home/office.

Laptops: Portable, built-in screen/keyboard.

Tablets: Touchscreen, very portable (iPad, Samsung Tab).

Smartphones: Pocket-sized, always connected.

Servers: Powerful computers that provide services to many users.

Embedded systems: Computers in other devices (car, washing machine, **ATM**).

Singapore widely uses smartphones for payments, government services via Singpass app.

chapters.title: Introduction to Algorithms
chapters.description: Understanding sequences, patterns, and step-by-step instructions

sections.title: What is an Algorithm?
sections.content:
Algorithm = step-by-step instructions to complete a task.

Like a recipe for cooking! 

**Example:**

 Making Milo -
1.

Boil water
2.

Put 3 spoons Milo in cup
3.

Pour hot water
4.

Stir
5.

Enjoy! Algorithms must be: Clear (no confusion), Ordered (correct sequence), Finite (must end).

Singapore traffic lights use algorithms to control light changes based on traffic flow and time.

sections.title: Sequences & Patterns
sections.content:
Sequence is ordered list: 2, 4, 6, 8 (adding 2 each time).

Pattern is repeating design: Red, Blue, Red, Blue.

Finding patterns helps solve problems faster. 

**Example:**

 Singapore bus numbers - 14, 14A, 14e follow pattern (same route, different stops).

Number patterns: 5, 10, 15, 20 (multiply by 5).

Understanding patterns is key to computational thinking.

sections.title: Breaking Down Problems
sections.content:
**SI (International System of Units)** is the standard measurement system used worldwide in science.

**The seven SI base units:**

1. **Meter (m)** - Length/distance
2. **Kilogram (kg)** - Mass
3. **Second (s)** - Time
4. **Ampere (A)** - Electric current
5. **Kelvin (K)** - Temperature
6. **Mole (mol)** - Amount of substance
7. **Candela (cd)** - Luminous intensity

**Why SI units?**

ğŸ”¹ Universal standard for scientific communication
ğŸ”¹ Easy conversion between units (based on powers of 10)
ğŸ”¹ Precise and consistent measurements

**Common SI units in Singapore:**

ğŸ”¹ **Length**: Meters (m) - MRT track lengths, building heights
ğŸ”¹ **Mass**: Kilograms (kg) - Body weight, food portions at hawker centers
ğŸ”¹ **Time**: Seconds (s) - Race timing at Singapore Sports Hub
ğŸ”¹ **Temperature**: Celsius (Â°C) - Weather reports (27-28Â°C average)

**Examples:**
- Height of Singapore Flyer: 165 m
- Mass of a durian: ~2 kg
- Daily temperature: 27Â°C (300 K)

sections.title: Focus on What Matters
sections.content:
Abstraction means ignoring unnecessary details, focusing on important information. 

**Example:**

 Singapore **MRT **map - Shows stations and lines, but **NOT **exact distances or street names.

That's abstraction - only essential info shown.

When giving directions: 'Take Red Line to Orchard, then Green Line to Bugis' - abstract (simple).

Not: 'Travel 2.3km northeast, turn at 103.8Â° heading...' - too detailed.

Abstraction makes problems simpler.

chapters.title: Block-Based Programming
chapters.description: Introduction to programming using visual blocks (Scratch/Blockly)

sections.title: What is Block Programming?
sections.content:
Block programming uses colorful blocks instead of typing code.

Snap blocks together like **LEGO**! Popular tools: Scratch (**MIT**), Blockly (Google), Code.org.

Blocks include: Motion (move sprite), Looks (change appearance), Sound (play music), Events (when clicked), Control (if/repeat). 

**Example:**

 Make Singapore Merlion sprite move - 'When green flag clicked' + 'Move 10 steps' + 'Say Hello for 2 seconds'.

No typing errors, focus on logic!

sections.title: Sequence - Order Matters
sections.content:
Sequence = blocks run in order from top to bottom. 

**Example:**

 Singapore flag animation -
1.

Set background to red
2.

Draw white crescent
3.

Draw 5 stars
4.

Play national anthem.

If order wrong (anthem before drawing), looks strange! Programs execute one instruction at a time, in sequence.

Practice: Create program to introduce yourself -
1.

Say name
2.

Show age
3.

Say school
4.

Say hobby.

sections.title: Loops - Repetition
sections.content:
Loops repeat actions. 'Repeat 10' block runs code 10 times. 'Forever' loop runs continuously. 

**Example:**

 Draw square - Repeat 4 times: Move 50 steps, Turn 90 degrees.

Without loop, need to write same code 4 times! Singapore **EZ**-Link card tapping - Loop checks: While balance > 0, allow entry. 'Repeat until' loops until condition is true.

Use loops to avoid repetitive code.

sections.title: If-Then - Making Decisions
sections.content:
If-Then blocks make decisions.

Structure: 'If condition Then action'. 

**Example:**

 Singapore weather program - 'If temperature > 30, Say Very Hot!, Else Say Pleasant'.

Conditions use comparisons: = (equal), > (greater), < (less).

Combination: 'If raining **AND **temperature < 25, Say Cold rain'.

Singapore school attendance - 'If student present, Mark attendance, Else Send absence alert'.

Computers make millions of if-then decisions per second.

sections.title: Common File Types
sections.content:
Files have extensions showing type.

Documents: .docx (Word), .pdf (Adobe), .txt (plain text).

Images: .jpg/.jpeg (photos), .png (graphics with transparency), .gif (animations).

Videos: .mp4, .avi, .mov.

Audio: .mp3, .wav.

Programs: .exe (Windows).

Compressed: .zip (multiple files).

Singapore government forms often in .pdf format.

Each type needs specific program to open - can't open .docx with media player!

sections.title: Files & Folders
sections.content:
Folders (directories) organize files.

Like filing cabinet! Good structure: School/ â†’ Math/, Science/, English/ â†’ each has assignments/.

Path shows location: C:/Users/Student/Documents/School/Math/Homework.docx.

Root folder is top level (C: on Windows).

Use meaningful names: 'Math_Homework_Week5.docx' not 'untitled123.docx'.

Singapore students organize by subject and term for easy retrieval.

Backup important files to cloud (Google Drive, OneDrive) or external drive.

chapters.title: Internet & Online Safety
chapters.description: How the internet works and staying safe online

sections.title: How the Internet Works
sections.content:
Internet = worldwide network of connected computers.

When you visit website:
1.

Type **URL** (www.moe.gov.sg)
2.

Computer sends request through router
3.

Request travels through many routers worldwide
4.

Reaches web server
5.

Server sends webpage back to you.

All in milliseconds! **IP **address is computer's location (like postal code). **DNS **translates website names to **IP **addresses.

Singapore has excellent internet infrastructure - fast fiber broadband connections.

sections.title: Staying Safe Online
sections.content:
Online safety rules:
1.

Never share passwords
2.

Don't give personal info (**NRIC**, address, phone) to strangers
3.

Think before posting - internet is permanent
4.

Tell adult if something uncomfortable
5.

Use privacy settings on social media.

Strong passwords: 8+ characters, mix letters/numbers/symbols, different for each site. 

**Example:**

 'S1ng@p0re#2024' (but don't use this - make your own!).

Singapore Cyber Security Agency (**CSA**) provides safety resources.

sections.title: Common Online Threats
sections.content:
Cyberbullying: Mean messages, spreading rumors online - report to adults/teachers.

Phishing: Fake emails/messages trying to steal passwords - don't click suspicious links.

Malware/Viruses: Harmful software - use antivirus, don't download from untrusted sources.

Scams: Too-good-to-be-true offers - 'Win free iPhone!' likely fake.

Identity theft: Someone pretends to be you - protect personal info.

Singapore Police Force website (scamalert.sg) lists current scams to watch for.

sections.title: Your Digital Footprint
sections.content:
Digital footprint = trail of data you leave online.

Everything you post, like, share stays online - maybe forever! Future employers, schools can search your name.

Tips:
1.

Google yourself - see what others find
2.

Set social media to private
3.

Don't post anything embarrassing
4.

Be kind online - messages can be screenshot
5.

Think: Would I want teachers/parents to see this? Singapore schools emphasize positive digital citizenship. 

**Remember:**

 'What happens online, stays online.'

chapters.title: Algorithms & Flowcharts
chapters.description: Algorithm design, flowcharts, pseudocode, and problem-solving strategies

sections.title: What are Algorithms?
sections.content:
An algorithm is a step-by-step procedure to solve a problem.

Like a recipe for cooking or directions to a destination.

In computing, algorithms tell computers exactly what to do. 

**Example:**

 Singapore **MRT **route planning - finding shortest path from Jurong East to Changi Airport involves an algorithm that considers all possible routes and selects the optimal one.

sections.title: Flowchart Symbols
sections.content:
Flowcharts use standard symbols: Oval (Start/End), Rectangle (Process/Action), Diamond (Decision/Question), Parallelogram (Input/Output), Arrow (Flow direction). 

**Example:**

**ATM **withdrawal flowchart - Check**PIN** â†’ Verify balance â†’ Decision: Sufficient funds? â†’ If Yes: Dispense cash, If No: Display error.

sections.title: Pseudocode Basics
sections.content:
Pseudocode is plain language description of algorithm steps, between human language and programming code.

Uses keywords like **IF**,**THEN**,**ELSE**,**WHILE**,**FOR**,**INPUT**,**OUTPUT**.

Example for finding max of 3 numbers:**INPUT **num1, num2, num3 /**IF **num1 > num2**AND **num1 > num3**THEN **max = num1 /**ELSE IF **num2 > num3**THEN **max = num2 /**ELSE **max = num3 /**OUTPUT **max

sections.title: Algorithm Efficiency
sections.content:
Efficient algorithms use fewer steps and resources.

Linear search checks each item one-by-one (slow for large lists).

Binary search divides search space in half each step (much faster for sorted lists). 

**Example:**

 Finding contact in phone with 1000 entries - Linear: up to 1000 checks, Binary: max 10 checks.

Singapore government systems process millions of transactions daily, efficiency is critical.

chapters.title: Python Programming Basics
chapters.description: Introduction to Python programming - variables, data types, input/output, basic operations
objectives: Use variables and data types correctly

sections.title: Introduction to Python
sections.content:
Python is a beginner-friendly programming language used worldwide.

Created by Guido van Rossum in
1991.

Used by Google, **NASA**, Singapore government agencies.

Easy to read: print('Hello Singapore!') displays text.

Python is interpreted - runs line by line.

Case-sensitive: 'Name' and 'name' are different.

sections.title: Variables & Data Types
sections.content:
Variables store data: age = 13, name = 'Ali', height = 1.
65.

Data types: int (whole numbers), float (decimals), str (text in quotes), bool (True/False).

Python auto-detects type. 

**Example:**

 price = 5.50 (float), quantity = 3 (int), total = price * quantity (result: 16.5). 

**Singapore context:**

 gst_rate = 0.09, total_with_gst = price * (1 + gst_rate)

sections.title: Input and Output
sections.content:
output: print() displays information. print('Welcome!') or print(age).

Input: input() gets user data as string. name = input('Enter your name: ').

Convert to number: age = int(input('Enter age: ')).

Example program: Calculate **MRT **fare - distance = float(input('Distance in km: ')) / fare = 0.77 + (distance * 0.
08. / print('Fare: $' + str(fare))

sections.title: Operators in Python
sections.content:
Arithmetic: + - * / (division) // (integer division) % (remainder) ** (power). 

**Example:**

 17 % 5 = 2 (remainder).

Comparison: == (equal) != (not equal) > < >= <=.

Returns True/False. 

**Example:**

 age >= 13 checks if teenager.

Logical: and, or, not. 

**Example:**

 if age >= 13 and age <= 19 then teenager.

Singapore **PSLE **score calculation uses these operators.

chapters.title: Selection & Iteration
chapters.description: Control structures - if/else statements, loops (for and while), nested structures
objectives: Use for loops for definite iteration
Use while loops for indefinite iteration

sections.title: If Statements
sections.content:
if statement makes decisions: if condition: do something.

Use indentation (4 spaces). 

**Example:**

 if age >= 18: print('Can vote'). elif (else if) for multiple conditions: if score >= 75: grade = 'A' / elif score >= 60: grade = 'B' / else: grade = 'C'.

Singapore O-Level grading uses multiple conditions.

sections.title: For Loops
sections.content:
for loop repeats known number of times. range(n) generates 0 to n-
1. 

**Example:**

 for i in range(5): print(i) outputs 0,1,2,3
4. range(start, stop, step): range(1, 10
2. gives 1,3,5,7
9.

Calculate total: total = 0 / for i in range(1, 6): total = total + i / Result:
15.

Used in Singapore bus arrival times app to check next 5 buses.

sections.title: While Loops
sections.content:
while loop repeats while condition is True. 

**Example:**

 count = 1 / while count <= 5: print(count) / count = count +
1.

Use when repetitions unknown. **ATM PIN **validation: attempts = 0 / while attempts < 3: pin = input('Enter **PIN**: ') / if pin == '1234': break / attempts = attempts + 1 / else: print('Card blocked'). 

**Important:**

 ensure loop eventually ends (no infinite loops).

sections.title: Nested Structures
sections.content:
Loops and if statements can be nested (one inside another). 

**Example:**

 Print multiplication table: for row in range(1, 4): / for col in range(1, 4): / product = row * col / print(product, end=' ') / print().

Singapore class seating arrangement uses nested loops to assign seats by row and column.

chapters.description: Working with lists (arrays) and string manipulation in Python

sections.title: Lists in Python
sections.content:
**SI (International System of Units)** is the standard measurement system used worldwide in science.

**The seven SI base units:**

1. **Meter (m)** - Length/distance
2. **Kilogram (kg)** - Mass
3. **Second (s)** - Time
4. **Ampere (A)** - Electric current
5. **Kelvin (K)** - Temperature
6. **Mole (mol)** - Amount of substance
7. **Candela (cd)** - Luminous intensity

**Why SI units?**

ğŸ”¹ Universal standard for scientific communication
ğŸ”¹ Easy conversion between units (based on powers of 10)
ğŸ”¹ Precise and consistent measurements

**Common SI units in Singapore:**

ğŸ”¹ **Length**: Meters (m) - MRT track lengths, building heights
ğŸ”¹ **Mass**: Kilograms (kg) - Body weight, food portions at hawker centers
ğŸ”¹ **Time**: Seconds (s) - Race timing at Singapore Sports Hub
ğŸ”¹ **Temperature**: Celsius (Â°C) - Weather reports (27-28Â°C average)

**Examples:**
- Height of Singapore Flyer: 165 m
- Mass of a durian: ~2 kg
- Daily temperature: 27Â°C (300 K)

sections.title: List Operations
sections.content:
Slicing: numbers[1:4] gets elements at index 1,2,
3. numbers[:3] first 3 elements. numbers[2:] from index 2 to end.

Concatenate: list1 + list
2.

Repeat: [0] * 5 creates [0,0,0,0,0].

Check membership: if 'Ali' in students.

Sort: numbers.sort() arranges in order.

Reverse: numbers.reverse().

Used in Singapore e-commerce sites to manage shopping cart items.

sections.title: String Manipulation
sections.content:
Strings are sequences of characters.

Access like lists: name = 'Singapore' / name[0] is 'S'.

Length: len(name) =
9.

Methods: upper(), lower(), strip(), split(), replace(). 

**Example:**

 message = '  Hello World  ' / message.strip() removes spaces = 'Hello World' / message.split() creates ['Hello', 'World'].

Check substring: if 'ore' in name (True).

Used in Singapore **NRIC **validation.

sections.title: Iterating Through Collections
sections.content:
Use for loop to process each element.

For list: for student in students: print(student).

For string: for char in 'Singapore': print(char).

With index: for i in range(len(students)): print(i, students[i]). 

**Example:**

 Calculate average - scores = [85, 92, 78, 90] / total = 0 / for score in scores: total = total + score / average = total / len(scores).

Singapore temperature monitoring system processes daily readings this way.

chapters.title: Functions & Modules
chapters.description: Creating reusable functions, parameters, return values, and using Python modules

sections.title: Defining Functions
sections.content:
Function is reusable block of code.

Define with def: def greet(): / print('Hello!').

Call: greet().

With parameters: def greet(name): / print('Hello ' + name + '!').

Multiple parameters: def add(a, b): / result = a + b / return result. 

**Example:**

 Singapore **GST **calculator - def add_gst(price): / gst = price * 0.09 / total = price + gst / return total

sections.title: Return Values
sections.content:
return sends value back to caller.

Function stops at return. 

**Example:**

 def max_of_two(a, b): / if a > b: return a / else: return b.

Use returned value: largest = max_of_two(10,
15. / print(largest).

Can return multiple values as tuple: def min_max(numbers): / return min(numbers), max(numbers).

Singapore grade calculator returns grade and points.

sections.title: Variable Scope
sections.content:
Local variables exist only inside function.

Global variables exist everywhere. 

**Example:**

 total = 0 (global) / def add_score(score): / total = total + score (Error! Can't modify global in function) / Use global keyword or pass as parameter.

Best practice: minimize global variables. 

**Example:**

 Singapore point-of-sale system uses local variables in each transaction function for safety.

sections.title: Python Modules
sections.content:
Module is file containing Python code you can import.

Built-in modules: math, random, datetime.

Import: import math / math.sqrt(
16. = 4.
0.

Import specific: from random import randint / dice = randint(1, 6).

Create own module: Save functions in file 'mytools.py', then import mytools.

Singapore apps use datetime module for scheduling: from datetime import datetime / now = datetime.now() / print(now.strftime('%d/%m/%Y %H:%M'))

sections.title: Semantic HTML
sections.content:
Semantic tags describe meaning: <header>, <nav>, <main>, <article>, <section>, <aside>, <footer>.

Better than generic <div>. 

**Example:**

 Singapore school website - <header> contains logo and menu, <nav> has navigation links, <main> contains main content, <article> for news posts, <footer> for contact info.

Benefits: Accessibility (screen readers), **SEO** (search engines understand structure).

sections.content:
Box model: content, padding, border, margin.

Display: block (full width), inline (in line), flex (flexible layout).

Position: static, relative, absolute, fixed.

Responsive design adapts to screen sizes.

Media queries: @media (max-width: 600px) { /** mobile styles **/ }.

Singapore government sites use responsive design for mobile access.

Flexbox example: display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;

chapters.title: Introduction to Computing
chapters.description: Understanding computers and their role in society

sections.content:
Computing is the study of how computers work and how to use them to solve problems.

Computers are everywhere in modern life - in our phones, homes, schools, and workplaces.
